review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

It's on sale for $0.39? Go ahead and buy it! It's about 1.5 hours of gameplay. 

The puzzles aren't entirely difficult but they hold your attention enough and required a bit of thinking or trial-and-error depending on how much you want to think or mindlessly play. The jumping is a little spooky aiming for the platforms but luckily there are few platforming parts and only the final level was a bit frustrating due to jumping. (I might just be bad at platformers).

Some of the tools used to change colors of the items were a little confusing to use but not too much - I think they add to the puzzle solving aspect in a positive way.

I didn't have any of the issues from the older negative reviews. The items respawned just fine, if I messed up I could always jump into the lava to restart the level (but there was little need for that), there was in-game music with a volume slider (and it started up muted music so no ear pains from bad volume mixing!), and also the cards did properly drop.

review:
It's not professionally made, which is fine, but I also think that the idea behind it isn't very good. The game pushes colours as the core mechanic, but colours alone aren't enough to carry a game, they need to supplement something greater. Most of the puzzles just revolve around mixing and matching colours which is unfortunately quite boring.

And on the topic of it being not professionally made, the biggest issue in that sphere (although there are many) is that there's no audio which makes it feel fairly un-finished, but I'll give them a pass on that. However, they're making a re-master/sequel called "Colortone Remixed" and that sours me on this game. It should just be an update and/or dlc to this; maybe they just don't know how to use Steamworks properly or something; or is it that they want to preserve this version of the game? But then they may aswell just make it a sequel, rather than a remaster/sequel. Point is though, is that it makes the people who bought the original feel cheated.

Anyways though, I'm sorry to say that I think these devs should move on from this game, either that or change it significantly; I just can't see the potential in a game that's only about colours. Although, they actually do push it pretty far, but I think that shows that they could make something much better, if they had a stronger core to begin with.

I still have no ideas how certain color coded gates are supposed to work because there are no "rules" that remain the same throughout. maybe it's a but but sometimes iwas able to walk through a color gate with my ball and have it stay colored, sometimes not (and i mean i repeated the same situation multiple times, same gate, same colored ball, ect). 
The levels also don't just add more mechanics to make it more "difficult" towards the end, it just adds more steps you have to complete in order so solve it. i've not stopped the time it took me to solve the levels but i looked up a video guide for the levels and the guy solves all 14 levels in ~50 minutes. Level 14 took 20+ (!!!!!) minutes in this video. this is honestly riddiculous! For the last 2-3 levels alone i cannot recommend the game, they are no more fun and for me ended up being a trial and error (either because the gates bugged out and i had to redo everything, and/or because i could never get behind the rules of these gates because they constantly bugged out)

review:
It's not professionally made, which is fine, but I also think that the idea behind it isn't very good. The game pushes colours as the core mechanic, but I think colours alone aren't enough to carry a game, they need to supplement something greater. Most of the puzzles just revolve around mixing and matching colours which I found boring.

And on the topic of it being not professionally made, the biggest issue in that sphere (although there are many) is that there's no audio which makes it feel fairly un-finished, but I'll give them a pass on that. However, they're making a re-master/sequel called "Colortone Remixed" and that sours me on this game. Remixed should just be an update and/or dlc to this; maybe they just don't know how to use Steamworks properly or something; or is it that they want to preserve this version of the game? But then they may aswell just make it a sequel, rather than a remaster/sequel. Point is though, is that it makes the people who bought the original feel cheated.

Anyways, my main issue remains with colours as the core mechanic. I don't think there's a lot of potential there, maybe that fact works well in a beginner project though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004464088', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1636907733}
review:
TLDR: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, NO MATTER HOW MUCH SALE IT IS ON.
I WOULD RATHER PAY NOT TO PLAY THIS GAME THAN TO PAY 0.01 EUR FOR IT

* Buggy.
* Bad level design
* Inconsistent game mechanics.
* Laggy even on a high-end machine. (6800 XT, Ryzen 5800X)
* NO SOUND OR MUSIC AT ALL!
* The screenshots on the store page shows solutions to some of the puzzles, spoiling them.

BUGGY:
*You cannot rotate platforms you are holding.
*My understanding of the controls was that you had an inventory, YOU DONT.
*When you toss a platform upon its supports, it flips 180 degrees.
*You sometimes sporadically fall through a platform while walking on it

BAD LEVEL DESIGN:
*Total of 14 puzzles, of which maybe 2-3 were good and actually made me think for a minute or two.
*I could find multiple ways to force through maybe 4-5 of the puzzles with "alternative solutions" that were NOT part of the game designers intention, breaking the game rules.

INCONSISTENCY:
*On some levels it is possible to get stuck without a way to progress, so that you have to restart the level to be able to win.
*On other levels it is impossible to get stuck, but instead it forces you to restart the level by doing so automatically??! Like WHY didn't you just implement that feature on all levels?

LAGGY:
*The game occasionally stutters and i get fps drop spikes playing a game that is 6 years old, on a brand new HIGH END COMPUTER in 2021...
* The gameplay is also just overall incredibly unsmooth.

NO SOUND:
*There is no sound at all in the game.
*No music, no nothing, not a single sound from any source.
Just graphics.

There are so many things that suck about this game.
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME
(Disclaimer: I finished the entire thing in 90 minutes of gameplay, it was not worth the time nor the money.)

review:
First off: I played about one hour, the rest is time I spent idling to drop trading cards.

I bought this game as someone recommended it for being similar to antichamber, I was looking for a mind-bending experience in that kind of style, after having played The Witness.

The graphic is simple and the mechanics fairly immediate to be understood.

Beyond the criticism I could move towards some of the puzzles, I can't in good conscious recommend this game: there is no music, so you'll walk around in a defening silence, broken every now and then by sporadic sound effects. However, the worst aspect is that the game misses "restart level" features, so that in certain levels you will have to quit to main menu and select the level you want to retry, in order to try it again. This is annoying in all those levels where you can lose (in places from which you can't retrive them) puzzle pieces essential to complete the level.
On top of this, my game became unplayable during level 7, where rotating the pillars caused my FPS to drop to 1-2 on a high end machine. (played RTX Cyberpunk 2077 all maxed out at launch)

This game feels like it's still in early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046656486', 'num_games_owned': 1098, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1590297802}
review:
TL;DR This game just isn't very good. Save your money and get something else if you're interested in a fun puzzle experience.

Something I haven't seen many other reviews mention is that the options menu purports to provide colorblind support, but the feature is worse than useless. First, selecting a type of colorblindness closes the main menu and leaves you on a blank title screen, forcing you to close the game. The next time you open the game and start playing, there will be a filter on top that simulates the type of colorblindness you selected. All these filters do is make it harder to distinguish colors, so removing the feature would at least make Colortone honest about its inaccessibility!

As for the game itself: Sound is off by default, but it's not worth turning it on because the music is just a small selection of repetitive tunes and there are almost no sound effects. The puzzles aren't very interesting and most hardly require any thought, but you'll need to perform plenty of repetitive actions to finish. There's some platforming here, but it's not very fun and sometimes even needlessly frustrating (as evidenced in the last level). The visual language isn't entirely consistent, either: I noticed that one of the buttons in the game is translucent, but another is opaque and seemed to be something to use a colored ball to interact with at first, but turned out to be something just to push.

There's also plenty of jankiness: objects will only sometimes respawn if they fall out of play, and death has inconsistent consequences. Sometimes you can reset the puzzle by dying, but other times dying will only put you back at the start without resetting anything, forcing you to return to the menu if you screwed up. The hit detection between planks and pegs is not always reliable, and I even had a plank fall between pegs when I was expecting it to land. Getting a ball to stay in a laser machine is difficult because rather than snap inside, the ball continues to roll inside the laser machine, requiring very precise placement to keep it from rolling out.

All I can say about this game that I actually liked is that most of the mechanics are pretty easy to understand without requiring explicit explanation. As long as you know how color mixing works and a few other basic things (e.g. green means go), you'll probably be able to figure out the puzzles in this game. However, Colortone is far from the only puzzle game to take this approach, and to give an example, Portal did it better despite releasing more than 8 years earlier.

On top of that, Portal is quite a bit longer, while Colortone has only 15 short levels! I ended up finishing in under 2 hours. There's way better games out there than this mediocre mess, and I wouldn't even recommend Colortone if it was free. Save your $4 (or however much less if it's on sale) and get a better game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210923713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1589529997}
review:
Negatives first: 
There are only 14 levels, the summation of which gave me 1.4 total hours of game play. The levels aren't difficult, and if you're looking for a difficult puzzle game this isn't it. 
I personally dislike the timers as they make me feel rushed; i'd rather sit back and enjoy the game. 
I personally dislike the jumps and platforming that is required. 
There should be a quick level restart in case a necessary component is lost or other (I might just be unaware that such a bind exists).

Positives: 
The game lets you explore functions of machines with no introduction; many larger titles force an introduction of functions on to you that I believe takes away from the experience as a whole.
It is nice to see a puzzle game with an new core mechanic (colors in this case).
At 1.83 USD at the time of this review, Colortone is cheap.

Overall Colortone is a very short, creative brainteaser that isn't too difficult. This being said, at the $1.2 USD per hour of entertainment i derived from this game, Colortone gets a thumbs up from me.

review: To sum it up, the game was pretty much like a colorful unfinished version of Portal. The game mechanics are there most of the time, there are a couple repetitive songs for the background music, and the puzzles are okay. It's a very short game, with only 14 levels. I first thought the game was still in development because on the second to last level, there's a huge glitch or something that made a white ball act like it was a green one, and it's a miracle I even got passed it. The final level being the only one where if you make a mistake, you reset the entire thing, which is challenging, but makes me question why it wasn't in the rest of the game. But I realized it must be a finished game when I saw it was made back in 2015. I'd have forgave the developers if they were still trying to work on it. But since they apparently abandoned it, I'd say getting this game is probably a waste despite it only being $1 max without discounts. I wouldn't recommend it, though someone could still play it since it is technically able to be completed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353244771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1563919611}
review:
[b] 4/5 - Decent [/b]

Not gonna lie, I did enjoy this game quite a lot! Even though there are only 14 puzzles, each one buids up on the previous ones yet bring something new, so I never felt bored. The puzzles themselves seem simple, but as you progress, may take some time to solve. I picked this game because I was looking for something easy, yet not boring to keep myself entertained for a couple of evenings, and this game nailed it. It's a good choice if you are looking for something not very long and not very serious. While there are some minor flaws which I'll get down to below, overall I got pretty good vibes from this game. 

[i]The graphics[/i]
Very nice for an indie game. Nothing to criticise there. I even liked it. It's not stunning, but it looks good. The colours aren't acid bright, the dominant colour of most of the surroundings is white, but nevertheless it's hard to get lost in the game because of the well placed lighting. Some keen eye will even notice subtile visual effects, for example if you look at a black line, you may notice some VHS effects. Very nice. 

[i]The music/ the sound[/i]
Leaves to wish for better. While I did like the tracks that the game had to offer, there were way too few of them, and the fact that they loop and may repeat right after had just finished playing, doesn't do it much justice. As I progressed I grew tired of it, so by the end of the game I just switched it off and played my music in the background. Another flaw is, there are no separate options for the ingame sounds volume and for the music volume, you can only turn down both at the same time. This requires more work to be done on. Anyway, the music and the sound in general aren't essential for the game, so you may say I'm just nitpicking. 

[i]The puzzles[/i]
As been said earlier, quite enjoyable. They do become more and more complicated by the end, and I like how the author keeps comming up with new techniques, almost every level brings you a new challenge. The only level I can't say I enjoyed as much as the rest was the last one, basically because it wasn't much of a puzzle, it was more of a parkour level. But other than that, the transitions between the levels, the levels themselves, all in general - felt quite pleasant. 

[u]Summing up,[/u] I definitelly recommend this game for purchase for its full price. The game knows its place and for what it can give, it takes accordingly. Hats off to the developer.

review:
Would I recommend the game? Well... no, but not because I don't like the game. If I'm to be completely honest here, I only found out about the game through a steam coupon, which I find pretty funny that they have a coupon for a 99 cent game that was abandoned years ago. But aside from that I think the game has potential, if it was given the chance. It's definitely a good start for a version 1 game but it's not actually good because it's been on version one for 4 years (if this is read in 2019). Don't get me wrong, I think it's a good first start game, but it's not something I'd go out of my way to play.

The Good Parts 
(I don't know how to do the bold blue text so bear with it)

The game itself is pretty fun when you start off. It's not the same consistant puzzles and though it's based on such a simple idea as mixing colors, it's good with having unique levels. I think it could also be used to maybe help younger kids as well to get the idea of colors and how they mix (since that's the whole point of the game). The music is fun and upbeat, I don't even know if it's original but it's got music so you aren't just walking around in silence.

The Bad Parts

I'm sorry, my list is a bit longer for this just because there's just so many things that could be improved. First, the controls don't make much sense. I don't understand why you have to use one key to pick objects up and the other to drop them. Why can't it just be both keys do both functions? Another problem with the game: the movement in general just feels so awkward and unnatural. You either leap over 10 feet or something or you're sometimes standing on air, there were countless times where I just wanted to make my person sprint to go faster because it's crazy how slow you walk but how far you can jump. I landed in the lava a few times because of that. Also, the items don't respawn if you accidentally toss them in the lava, just because it's hard to gauge how far you're going to toss them. And, there is an issue on level 2 as well where when you try to turn too fast, whatever you're holding goes absolutely insane. Not to mention, and this part might just be me, but the blurring of the screen when you fall isn't productive. I mean, on the first level it was great, I got spooked a little like I did something wrong, but after level 1 it gets tedious and it isn't something I look forward too.

So, do I recommend this game to whoever is reading? No, I don't. Don't let me stop you if you're just that desperate though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051304382', 'num_games_owned': 827, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1538433871}
review:
So, this is a game I bought three years ago. And I only got around to playing it today. However, it is bad enough that I wish I could refund it.

My main gripe with this game is the unnecessary platforming. It's not fun to have to lay down planks just to cross a pit of lava, then have to colour the planks, then lay them back down again, then cross, then lay them down across a different pit of lava, then colour them further... yet that is exactly the solution to the second level in the game. That's not fun. That's tedious. Oh, and if you drop a plank into the lava, you have to start all over again.

Hell, if you drop *anything* into lava, or if you fall into lava while holding an item, you have to start all over again, because while [i]you[/i] respawn, the item you were holding does not.

Except in one level where, if you jump into lava, it restarts the whole level. Nice and inconsistent.

But even without the unnecessary platforming, the puzzles mostly don't feel like a cohesive set of puzzles. The mechanics used in the puzzles are all over the place. There is a teleporter in an early level that teleports items from inside a room to outside the room; literally the only barrier there was the door, which doesn't allow the items to pass. The developer *literally* created a problem and then just gave us the solution directly, and decided that this counts as a puzzle. And that teleporter was used *only* in that one room, and nowhere else in the game that I was able to play up to.

Oh, and OF COURSE there's lava in that room. Why *wouldn't* be lava in that room? There's lava in every bloody room, even when the lava's not effing needed. Like, the teleporter is right next to the items, and the only reason that lava's there is so that you have a chance to fall off the narrow bridge between the door and the items.

Honestly, that room would have been improved if it had been integrated with the room that *required* the items you needed to teleport out. Then everything would have been in one room and you could see everything without having to explore through the labyrinthine hallways of the level.

Later levels introduce an overly-complex "magic box" that sucks colours out of an object and transforms them into colour pools (what you use to colour objects in the first place), which on its own isn't too bad, but they're really fiddly to use. You have to push an object into a tiny tiny space, then push a lever and wait. And wait. And wait. Yes, the walking speed is also slow in this game.

I guess I was wrong when I said earlier that my main gripe was the unnecessary platforming. No, on second thoughts I don't have a "main gripe". This game simply annoys in so many tiny little ways, and yet any one or two on their own would be acceptable in a normal good puzzle game. It's like a patient who walks into a normal GP who has diarrhoea, a broken leg (closed fracture), an arm bitten by a dog, and glandular fever. Any one of these would be a simple matter to treat, but all four at once is just a bad situation that no GP should ever have to deal with. But this game just doesn't really show much promise from the outset. The patient also has type II diabetes to start off with.

It's just not fun, and I think it's because the mechanics want to pull the game in one direction (clever recolouring puzzles), but the actual puzzles pull it in another (platforming and classic "adventure game" puzzles). The mechanics and the puzzles aren't in harmony, they are fighting against each other.

For instance, while the mechanic is all about recolouring balls and placing them in receptacles to activate things, there's one level where the "puzzle" is simply about looking at the receptacles (which are numbered out of order), then looking at a wall to see what colours go with each number, and then colouring the balls appropriately (not a difficult task since the colour pools are in the same room as the receptacles and the balls). This is the sort of puzzle where, when asked to find the height of a building with a inclinometer, the game just ties a rope to the inclinometer and lowers it onto the ground from the roof, then measures the length of the rope.

Honestly, this is just a game you should avoid period, even though I know my review is hardly convincing about that. I'd refund it, but I bought it three years ago, so I can't.

So yeah, a simple but interesting concept that is poorly executed and filled with bugs to the point of being borderline unplayable.

review:
I used to think that this game was terrible and a huge waste of money, but I recently had a change of heart. I guess I thought that this game was going to be like Antichamber when I first saw it, so I bought it. I then got stuck on the very first level and had to use a walkthrough because I thought it was confusing. I didn't really play it very much after I bought it...
One day, I decided to try the level that I was stuck on (Level 02). The level involved using strange board things to get to various areas you could use to recolor the ball. I was just about ready to give up and look up a video walkthrough when I discovered I could [spoiler] also recolor the boards themselves, too. [/spoiler] This proved to be one of the main elements I had to use to beat the level, and after that I started to like this game as much as I do Antichamber.
The game always seems to be adding new mechanics constantly, which maintains a nice pace. Every level so far has had at least one thing in it that is different from the previous, which I like a lot.
There is one important thing that I realized when I finally beat Level 02: [b] You need to experiment with the game to beat it. [/b]
This makes perfect sense if you look at certain elements of the game. Unlike Antichamber, there are ways to die in the game. The thing is, though, that you [b] don't fail if you die [/b], which leads to some VERY interesting solutions. Sometimes dying is the only way to solve a puzzle, or, at least, the most obvious way.
I have encountered a few glitches so far. Sometimes a ball will unexplainably warp and stretch if it isn't the right color for a square, which acts kind of like a button in Portal that needs a specific color. If a board falls in lava (Or whatever that red stuff is), it will usually respawn standing straight up. I haven't unlocked any of the acheivements that you get for beating a level yet, even though I am somewhere around Level 05 or 06. For the most part, however, the game is fine. It also runs smoothly on my computer, but that might be from the fact that it has something like 2 graphics cards in it. You can adjust the graphics quality anyway, so that might mean the game could even run on a fairly old computer, provided that the lowest graphics settings could permit that. There isn't really much in the way of graphics, as most of it is putting colored balls into squares. This doesn't bother me, though, as the relatively simple art style helps me focus on the gameplay.
My only real complaint is the soundtrack. I usually play without the sound on, and for (In my opionion) a great enough reason. At one point I randomly decided to turn the game volume up a little bit. I heard a little bit of what I think was a guitar song that carried over to a little bit of the start of the next level. I then heard a completely different-styled song that seemed to be mostly piano. The soundtrack is seemingly incoherent, as I can piece together just from listening to these two completely different-sounding tracks. There isn't any sound in the game other than the soundtrack as far as I can discern, though, so you won't be missing out on any important audio clues by having the game's sound turned off.
All in all, Colortone is a great little game that will reward that certain player that likes to experiment with a game to beat it. It does have a few bugs here and there, but these glitches don't ruin the gameplay for the most part.

review:
[h1]Pre-Completion Review[/h1]

Initially I found out about this game through an Antichamber thread, where Californ1a mentioned its similarity.  I am now finding other games like Parallax to be more similar to Antichamber than this one.  It seems the developers didn't take advantage of the early access that they were granted, as some quality features were lacking, including but not limited to: [list][*]I thought the game had no sound because the volume slider was all the way down by default.
[*]But there's more to it than that: there are almost no highly noticeable game sounds nor interesting music, and that is a big key to making any game memorable!
[*]Controls are a little weird when you first meet up with them, as there is no context sensitivity.
[*]The settings are minimal in-game because they've been moved to a dialog box outside of the game (eh, that's just the way the Unity game engine works though :P)
[*]Worst of all, [b]there appear to be situations where the player can get trapped and not be able to pass the level.  These can occur as early as level 2.[/b]  This is really annoying for a puzzle game.  At the least some sort of reset switch would be nice.[/list]

[h1]Post-Completion Review[/h1]

OK, now having completed the game, not much about my opinions above have changed.  I think the reason the game lasts a couple of hours for about a hour's worth of content is the game's bugginess.  In level 13 for instance, I got stuck for the longest time because I didn't realize one ball was colored because it appeared white.  That made a huge portion of the puzzle redundant after that simple realization.  As I said before, not enough debugging and testing was done on the game.

Also, along the way, a friend told me that the newly added achievements are broken.

Rating: 4/10.  It's not as bad as some games, and the concept is interesting, but it's rather poorly executed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082249063', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1449354939}
review:
[b]**[u] Key was provided by developer for review purposes	[/u]**[/b] 

[h1] Colortone	[/h1]

Colortone is an interesting Puzzle Adventure Indie game where you use colors to solve different puzzles. I will provide a TL;DR at the end.  

[h1] Gameplay	[/h1]

Currently there are 14 (15 if you include level 0) levels to play through. The first few levels could be seen as tutorials to show you the different features and ways to beat puzzles within the game. Everything within Colortone is linked with using colors, whether it be to finish the level, destroy a wall, or to make a platform. There are 6 colors within Colortone which are the 3 primary colors (blue, red, and yellow) and the 3 secondary colors (purple, orange, and green). There are 2 types of object you can color according to which dab of colour you put it in, a small sphere and a board. You can dip these in individual colors or you can dip in one, then another, to create a secondary color. The game uses an interesting platforming idea where you place your boards on certain colored rods and if the board matches the colored rod then it have created a platform for you to jump on. There are also machines which use the sphere colored with primary colors to create its secondary colors (Example: blue would create green and purple), secondary colors create their individual primary colors (Example: green would create blue and yellow), and a machine which will take the color of the sphere and put it down so you can use it (Example blue means you get blue). There are certainly a lot of good puzzle elements which can be utilized within Colortone to make sure it is a very pleasant experience.

[h1] Graphics/Sound[/h1]

Colortone has an amazing soundtrack that is able to easily ease you into a calm mood to play through and enjoy the game. The graphics are fairly basic, nothing that stand out that much. The game will be mostly white except for the colors seen in walls, platforms, spheres, machines, light beam, and everything you can use/have to go through to beat the level and lava.

[h1]Pros/Cons	[/h1]

[b] Pros	[/b]

+ Good concept
+ Great use of color within puzzles to solve them
+ Good soundtrack
+ Fun gameplay
+ Options for colorblind to allow for them to enjoy this game

[b] Cons	[/b]

- Very limited replay value (only 15 levels)
- Beatable within 2 hours
- Some levels have a slight problem where if you die with an object and lose it, you are unable to obtain it and have to restart
- Unable to run on Windows 10 (at the moment)

[h1] Suggestions[/h1]

These are my personal suggestions to the game that I feel will change the game for the better. 

- An in-game editor to allow players to create their own levels along with a sharing feature to play other people's maps
- More campaign maps

[h1] Final Thoughts	[/h1]

I was able to enjoy almost all of my time spent within Colortone, but I was disappointed to find out that there were only 15 levels with nothing else. This game would be drastically improved if it had an editor with the map to create custom maps. 

[h1] TL;DR	[/h1]

Colortone is a very interesting and fun to play puzzle game that utilizes colors. The game is currently around 2 hours to beat with only 15 levels. The soundtrack does a nice job in immersing you into the game and makes for a more relaxing experience. If you like the look of the game and have the $5 lying around you might consider purchasing this for yourself as it's a good experience with everything that is within the game so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033370644', 'num_games_owned': 3212, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1454011289}
review:
[h1]General Info[/h1]
I originally picked this up when I heard about it during the Co-Optional Podcast's releases section when TB mentioned it looked Antichamber-esk. With me being one of the few people who have hundreds of hours in Antichamber (speedrunning/routing), it looked like an obvious game to pick up, and upon buying it (during it's early access period), noticed it had a "Speedrun" mode button on the main menu, which appealed to me. At the time, it wasn't a functional mode, and was just a placeholder button. I livestreamed my first play of the early access version, and promptly posted [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/375320/discussions/0/541906348033859341/]here[/url] on the community discussions what my thoughts were (along with some bugs).

[h1]Developer[/h1]
The dev is very nice and responsive in the community discussions, however this is where the game starts to get a few demerits from me. I realize making a game can be time consuming, and plenty of other things can be much more important, but the dev had specifically assigned dates for each new level to come out. This schedule worked fine for the majority of the levels, however near the last few levels, the dev missed releasing about 3 or 4 levels in a row, constituting about 2 months of no updates, with no word from the dev about when updates would come. The only information was via [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/375320/discussions/0/528398719793253704/]this thread[/url] on the community discussions. The dev also does not maintain any active news/announcements posts or changelogs so when the game does update, you have no idea what has changed, and you can't look back at any "previous" changelogs because none exist.

[h1]Schedule[/h1]
Mid-August was meant to be the release for the first level that was skipped, and as seen in the thread linked above, the dev said that all the final levels as well as speedrun mode would be finished by the end of September. Nearing the end of October is when the update finally arrived, without speedrun mode, and with two broken levels. The bugged levels were promptly fixed, as I have already said the dev is responsive on the community discussions.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
Sure there are bugs, but nothing too major. Any major bugs I've seen (and posted about) have been promptly fixed by the dev. Again, as I said above, the dev is quite responsive for this kind of stuff. The only main bugs I can think of currently are that some objects can get stuck inside walls/floor, but it can be looked at as a quirk of the game and just takes some getting used to how to control yourself when carrying an object. I've found that the controls themselves are fine for my tates, as opposed to what some of the other reviews say about the right/left mouse functions, just takes some getting used to.

[h1]Speedrun Mode[/h1]
There is no information regarding speedrun mode at the time of posting this, and last I checked, the button in the main menu has been removed, and the game has come out of early access, so I feel as though the dev has dropped the idea completely.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
$5 is pretty cheap, so I would recommend it, and the game itself as-is right now is still pretty great for that price, however I do feel like there are a lot of things the dev could have done better during the early access time period, such as posting changelogs (or even having version numbers to begin with), or news posts about any delays or changes of ideas/direction.

good morning jesus! good morning sinners! what bundle key has the almighty blessed me with today?  oooh a color game!  this one used to be called colorblind, but black people found that offensive so now it is called colortone. let us go ahead and give it a try. how bad can it be when jesus is my co-pilot.

to start, as soon as you get into the first level, a screen with simple control directions pops up. you read it for about 10 seconds and then you want it to go away so you can start, it does say 'press h to quit'. this is the best advice an evil sinner dev can give. don't stop at pressing the 'h' key. turn off your computer, go outside, or just do anything short of suicide(that is a sin and the devil gets your soul) to avoid playing this. it turned out that after 30 seconds of anger i realized that the evil sinner dev meant to say 'press h to continue'. i must advise against that however.

visually, it looks like a game that requires 3-d glasses to play.  if i play this for more than 20 minutes, i will projectile vomit all over my pc. no worries there though, because the game is so short that nobody will ever play for that long. 

anyway, you have to take a ball and change it to the right color. there is a box with blue color and a box with red color etc. you need to put your ball into the right color or combination of colors to progress.  sounds easy enough, right? 2 weeks out of your mother's womb you knew that yellow and blue made green. it is never that easy, of course.

lets say you want to make green. you put your ball into the blue color square thing on the floor, and all is good. now you need to put it into the yellow square. here is where the game goes completely to shit.  you have about half a second of your colorball turning green like you want it. if you don't move with lightning fast speed, the ball is going to stay in the yellow for too long and turn to yellow. i did that first stupid colorball probably 10 times before i managed to get it to stay green. this is the mechanic that the entire game is centered around, and it is all kinds of fucked up.

the final nail in the old body of christ for me was when i got to level 3 or 4. i went to carry one of the colorballs, but it was so big that it literally blocked 95% of the screen. i can't play if i can't see. you can't tell me this was tested and someone just decided it was fine that nobody could see what they were doing. occasionally, the giant colorbll morphed into a giant colordonut so i could see through the middle, but i don't think that was intentional.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=473698606  

so thats it. i'm never playing again. somehow i made it through half of the game anyway. it is not exactly bursting with content. 

lets all try something here before we go.  get a blue bible and a yellow bible. smash them together to make a green bible. now go throw it in the trash. that is where this game belongs. at least i would give you steam trading cards and a 'you threw away the bible you are going to hell' achievement.

god bless amen
